title: Smart Pill Dispenser — STM32-Based Medication Management System

sections.title: Project Background
sections.content: The Smart Pill Dispenser was focused on improving medication management in both hospital and home-care environments. It addresses common medication errors caused by forgetfulness, manual scheduling, and human oversight, especially among elderly users and busy healthcare staff. The system is built using an STM32 microcontroller and automates pill dispensing at scheduled times while confirming dispensing activity through sensors.

sections.title: Problem
sections.content: Many patients, particularly elderly users, forget to take medication or accidentally take it more than once. In hospital settings, manual medication handling increases staff workload and raises the risk of missed or incorrect doses during busy routines.

sections.title: Solution
sections.content: The system automates medication dispensing by releasing pills at predefined times and verifying the dispensing process using sensors. This reduces reliance on memory and manual handling, improving medication safety and consistency. In normal mode, the dispenser runs its scheduled cycles automatically, while configuration mode (unlocked via RFID and keypad input) is used by authorised staff to adjust or update medication timings before returning to normal operation.

sections.alt: Working principle of the smart pill dispenser
sections.caption: Illustration showing the pill dispensing mechanism, sensor detection, and control flow

sections.title: My Role
items: Programmed STM32 microcontroller using Embedded C++.
Integrated RTC, RFID, IR sensor, and servo motor.
Debugged electrical wiring and firmware issues.
Tested system reliability and dispensing accuracy.

sections.alt: System block diagram of the smart pill dispenser
sections.caption: Block diagram showing the STM32 microcontroller, input sensors, user interfaces, and output devices

sections.title: System Flow & Operation
items: System starts in normal operating mode after power-up.
Authorised staff can enter configuration mode using RFID authentication.
In configuration mode, the keypad is used to set or update medication schedules.
Configuration options and system status are shown on the OLED display.
RTC continuously keeps track of the current time.
When a scheduled dispensing time is reached, the STM32 triggers the dispensing process.
Servo motor rotates to release a single pill.
IR sensor confirms whether a pill has been successfully dispensed.
PIR sensor detects user presence near the dispenser during operation.
System status, alerts, and feedback are displayed on the OLED and LCD screens.
After dispensing, the system returns to normal mode and waits for the next scheduled cycle.

sections.title: Outcomes
content: Our project was made possible by developing an automated pill dispensing system using STM32 firmware and Embedded C++, integrating RTC scheduling, servo control, and IR/PIR sensor feedback to ensure accurate and reliable dispensing. This design reduced missed or double doses during testing and improved overall system safety through RFID-based configuration access that prevented unauthorised changes. The system was validated through repeated end-to-end prototype testing, demonstrating stable operation across multiple dispensing cycles.

items: Microcontroller: STM32F103RB
Programming Language: Embedded C++
Sensors: IR sensor, PIR sensor
Actuator: Servo motor
Modules: RFID RC522, RTC DS3231
Displays: OLED (SSD1306), LCD
Application Area: Healthcare automation

title: IoT-Based Supermarket Self-Checkout System
role: IoT Systems Developer | Embedded & Software Engineer

sections.title: Project Background
sections.content: This project is an IoT-based Supermarket Self-Checkout System designed to improve shopping efficiency by allowing customers to independently scan items, manage purchases, and complete payments. The system supports both in-store and online purchases, including membership authentication, QR code generation for in-store pickup, and secure payment handling.

sections.title: Problem
sections.content: Traditional supermarket checkout systems often result in long queues, high manpower dependency, and inefficient transitions between in-store and online shopping workflows, negatively impacting customer experience during peak hours.

sections.title: Solution
sections.content: A unified self-checkout solution was developed using a Raspberry Pi as the central controller, integrating Picamera-based barcode scanning, RFID authentication, cart management, and payment processing. In addition to in-store checkout, the system includes an online shopping website where users can browse products, add items to a cart, and place orders remotely. Product information, user/cart data, and orders are stored and managed in a MariaDB database. For online pickup orders, the system generates a QR code containing an Order ID to enable fast in-store pickup verification. Power management logic was implemented to reduce energy consumption by dynamically switching between low and high power operating modes.

sections.title: Use Case Diagram
sections.alt: Use case diagram for supermarket self-checkout system
sections.caption: Use case diagram illustrating interactions between in-store customers, online customers, payment gateway, and backend systems

sections.title: Use Case Diagram Explanation
sections.content:
The use case diagram illustrates the functional interactions between different actors and the supermarket self-checkout system. In-store customers initialize the system, scan items using a camera, and complete payments. The scanning workflow includes continuous item verification against the product database, followed by cart total calculation and checkout confirmation. Optional membership authentication is performed using RFID, extending the payment process with additional validation steps.

Online customers interact with the system through a website to browse products, add items to the cart, and complete checkout remotely. The website communicates with a MariaDB database to retrieve product details and store cart/order information. For online pickup purchases, the system generates a QR code containing an Order ID, which is scanned during in-store pickup for verification. The payment gateway supports payment methods such as ATM card, PayWave/RFID, and Visa, while backend services handle authentication, item validation, and order summary generation.

sections.title: Hardware & Interface Architecture
sections.caption: Hardware interface architecture showing sensors, input devices, and output peripherals connected to the Raspberry Pi

sections.title: Hardware Architecture Explanation
sections.content:
The hardware architecture is centered around a Raspberry Pi development board, which serves as the main controller for all system operations. A camera module connected via the CSI port performs barcode scanning for item identification. An RFID reader interfaced through GPIO and SPI pins enables membership authentication, while a keypad connected to GPIO pins allows user input for menu navigation and checkout control.

An ultrasonic sensor connected to GPIO pins is used to detect object presence and system interaction states. Output devices include an LCD connected through the I2C interface for displaying menus, item details, and payment information, as well as a buzzer connected to a GPIO pin to provide audio feedback during authentication and system events. This modular hardware design ensures reliable real-time interaction between sensors, user interfaces, and backend software components.

sections.title: System Flow & Operation
items: System powers on and displays the main menu on the LCD interface
User initiates checkout and begins scanning items using the camera
Scanned items are validated against the product database and added to the cart
System continuously updates and displays the cumulative total
User optionally performs RFID-based membership authentication
Payment is processed securely through the payment system
For online orders, a QR code is generated and scanned during in-store pickup verification
System transitions between high and low power modes based on activity state

sections.title: Outcomes
sections.content: The system was successfully implemented based on a structured requirements specification covering item scanning, authentication, payment workflows, online ordering with QR-based pickup verification, and dynamic power management. Functional testing validated end-to-end operation across in-store and online scenarios, demonstrating reliable system behavior and effective energy-saving transitions between Low Power Mode and High Power Mode.

sections.title: Key Functional Features
items: System startup and main menu display on LCD with keypad navigation
In-store item scanning using camera-based barcode detection
Real-time cart management and cumulative price calculation
Optional member authentication using RFID with buzzer feedback
Secure in-store payment processing
Online shopping support with QR code generation for in-store pickup verification
Low Power Mode (LPM): Activated when the user exits the system or when no high-power activity is detected for a defined inactivity period to conserve energy
High Power Mode (HPM): Activated during scanning, database lookup, cart updates, authentication, payment processing, and QR code generation

sections.title: Technical Summary
items: Controller: Raspberry Pi
Programming Language: Python
Online Platform: Website (Online Shopping)
Database: MariaDB (Products, Cart, Orders)
Item Detection: Camera-based Barcode Scanning
Authentication Module: RFID Reader
Presence Detection: Ultrasonic Sensor
User Interface: LCD Display (I2C), Keypad
Feedback Device: Buzzer
Order Verification: QR Code Generation
Power Management: Low Power Mode (LPM), High Power Mode (HPM)
Application Area: Smart Retail & IoT Automation

title: Self-Navigating Soil Tiller Robot — Arduino-Based Field Prototype
role: Embedded Systems Developer & Tester | Sensor Integration & Control Logic

sections.title: Project Background
sections.content: This project focuses on reducing manual agricultural labour by developing an autonomous soil tilling robot. The system navigates a predefined path while collecting soil and environmental data, improving efficiency and reducing physical workload.

sections.title: Problem
sections.content: Traditional soil tilling is labour-intensive, time-consuming, and energy-draining, especially in high-temperature environments. Manual cultivation requires continuous human effort and contributes to increased energy consumption, making it inefficient and unsustainable for long-term agricultural practices. These challenges highlight the need for automation to improve efficiency while supporting sustainable agricultural development.

sections.title: Solution
sections.content: To address these challenges, this project introduces an autonomous soil tilling robot that automates navigation and soil monitoring tasks. By integrating sensors, control logic, and actuators, the system reduces reliance on manual labour, optimizes energy usage, and improves operational efficiency. The solution aligns with UN Sustainable Development Goal 9 by promoting innovation, efficiency, and sustainable agricultural technology.

sections.title: Block Diagram
sections.caption: Block diagram showing the relationship between the Arduino controller, sensors, actuators, and display.

sections.title: System Components & Operation
items: The system initializes the Arduino controller, sensors, and motors upon power-up.
IR sensors enable autonomous line-following navigation along a predefined path.
An ultrasonic sensor continuously monitors for obstacles and halts movement when required to prevent collisions.
Soil moisture and environmental sensors collect soil condition, temperature, and humidity data during operation.
Based on sensor input, the servo motor and linear actuator control mechanical movement and watering-related actions.
Real-time sensor readings and system status are displayed on the LCD for user feedback and monitoring.

sections.title: Prototype Behaviour Observation
sections.content: During testing, the robot demonstrated stable line-following behaviour and reliable obstacle detection. Sensor readings were updated consistently on the LCD, validating both the firmware logic and hardware integration. In addition, soil moisture readings were used to determine whether watering was required, where the linear servo actuator was lowered to perform watering when low moisture was detected and remained inactive when sufficient moisture was present.

sections.content: This demonstration reflects the application of Industry 4.0 concepts in agriculture, where sensors, automation, and control logic are integrated to enable data-driven decision-making. By automating soil condition assessment and navigation, the system reduces reliance on manual labour while supporting smarter and more sustainable farming practices.

sections.title: Outcomes
content: This project developed an autonomous soil tiller that automated soil monitoring and navigation through integrated sensing and control. Soil moisture data was used to guide watering decisions, and prototype demonstrations validated the application of Industry 4.0 concepts in agriculture.

title: Trash Segregator — IoT Waste Monitoring & Sorting Prototype
heroAlt: Smart bin introduction slide comparing traditional bin vs smart bin

sections.title: Project Background
sections.content: The Smart Trash Segregator is a concept-driven IoT solution designed to improve waste sorting efficiency in public and residential environments. The project focuses on reducing user confusion and effort during waste disposal by introducing automated sorting, guided feedback, and optional remote monitoring. It supports sustainability goals by encouraging correct recycling behavior and reducing contamination in waste streams.

sections.title: Problem
sections.content: Many users struggle with proper waste separation due to unclear bin categories, unpleasant handling, and lack of guidance, especially in public spaces. Manual sorting often leads to incorrect disposal, reduced recycling efficiency, and increased maintenance effort.

sections.title: User Interviews
sections.content: User interviews were conducted with housewives and members of the public to understand current challenges in waste disposal. Housewives highlighted difficulties in determining whether bins were full, as there is no clear indication without opening the bin, often resulting in overflowing trash. Public users reported that bins in shared spaces, especially in HDB areas, are frequently full and that waste is often not properly separated into recyclable and general waste. These insights informed the need for clearer guidance, automated sorting, and improved bin capacity awareness in the system design.

sections.title: Solution
sections.content: The system introduces a smart bin that automatically detects waste characteristics and routes items into the correct compartment using a motorized sorting mechanism. Visual feedback is provided through indicator LEDs to guide users during disposal. Optional wireless connectivity enables remote monitoring of bin status, supporting maintenance planning and system scalability.

items.alt: System flow chart showing waste detection, decision logic, and actuator control
items.caption: Flow chart illustrating the system’s operational logic, including waste detection, classification, and actuator control sequence.

items.alt: Block diagram of hardware components and microcontroller connections
items.caption: Block diagram highlighting hardware inputs, microcontroller processing, and output modules such as actuators and indicators.

sections.title: System Architecture & Operational Flow
items: The system begins by initializing the microcontroller, sensors, indicators, and communication modules after power-up.
Ultrasonic rangers and the LDR continuously capture input data related to waste presence, bin level, and basic waste characteristics.
Bin identification is determined using DIP switch configuration, allowing the controller to differentiate between waste compartments.
The microcontroller processes all incoming sensor data and executes decision logic to classify waste and assess bin capacity.
Based on the control decision, a servo motor actuates the mechanical sorting mechanism to route waste into the appropriate bin.
Laser and red/green LED indicators provide immediate visual feedback to guide user interaction and indicate system status.
When bin sections reach capacity, the system triggers alerts and transmits status updates through the wireless module for monitoring.
The operation cycle completes after feedback and notification are delivered, readying the system for the next interaction.

sections.caption: Data flow diagram showing how sensor data is processed, transmitted, and visualized through cloud-based monitoring.

sections.title: Data Flow Diagram — Data Processing & Monitoring
items: Sensor nodes continuously collect waste level and status data during operation.
Collected sensor data is transmitted to a central controller for processing.
The controller analyses bin status and determines whether alerts or updates are required.
Relevant data is sent to cloud storage for logging and analysis.
A dashboard interface visualizes system status for monitoring and maintenance.

sections.content: A lightweight mobile monitoring interface was developed using MIT App Inventor to display the bin’s fill level received from the system’s wireless module. This enables quick remote checking of bin status without physically opening the bin, supporting faster response for clearing and maintenance.

title: SP Pals — Social Media App for Singapore Polytechnic Students
role: Mobile UI Developer, UX Flow & System Design
heroAlt: SP Pals app UI mockups showing home feed, search, profiles, chat and messaging

sections.title: At a Glance
sections.content: SP Pals is a student-focused social platform concept designed for Singapore Polytechnic. It centralises campus updates and student interaction features such as feeds, profiles, search, and messaging, supporting a more connected campus community experience.

sections.title: Problem
sections.content: Students rely on scattered sources (multiple apps and groups) to keep up with campus news and peer communication. This fragmentation makes it harder to discover updates, find communities, and interact efficiently in one place.

sections.title: Proposed Solution
sections.content: A single SP-centric social app that combines campus updates and student interaction. The design prioritises simple navigation, clear UI hierarchy, and familiar social patterns so students can adopt it quickly.

items.alt: Home, Profile, Settings and QR/Share screens

sections.title: Core Features
items: Home feed for campus-related posts and student updates
Search functionality to quickly find students and relevant content
User profiles to showcase student identity, activities, and posts
Integrated chat box for real-time messaging, powered by Firebase Realtime Database
Post filtering options to categorize content into CCA, Calendar, and Lost & Found sections
Notification system to keep users informed of activity and updates
Post creation flow for sharing announcements and updates

sections.title: UI/UX Design Decisions
sections.content: The interface follows familiar social app patterns to reduce learning time. Key flows (home → search → profile → chat) were mapped to minimise taps, and screens were designed with consistent layout and spacing to keep interaction predictable.

sections.title: Unique Functional Highlights
items: QR / share profile feature to connect quickly without typing usernames
Structured user flows for search → profile → chat to reduce friction
Post filters to support browsing and content organisation
Campus-focused positioning to differentiate from general social platforms

sections.title: My Role
sections.content: I focused on the UI/UX flow, Splash Screen and screen design planning, including navigation structure, interaction flow between main modules, and preparing polished mockups for evaluation.

sections.title: Outcome
sections.content: Designed a unified campus social app concept by consolidating feeds, search, profiles, and real-time messaging into a single platform, resulting in a clearer end-to-end user experience that reduces information fragmentation and improves student engagement within the campus community.
